Problem:
A mechanical system's position as a function of time is determined by the integro-differential equation \\( \\ddot{x} + p(t) \\dot{x} + q(t)x = \\int_0^t e^{-s}x(s) \\, ds \\) where \\( p(t) \\) and \\( q(t) \\) are given functions. We analyze the impact of a control intervention defined by the function \\( h(x) = x + ct^2 \\) where c is a constant.

If the initial conditions \\( x(0) \\) and \\( \\dot{x}(0) \\) are set, and then the system is allowed to evolve under the given equation without further intervention, will the position \\( x(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if the system started with modified initial conditions via the function \\( h(x) \\)?
Explanation: Applying the function \\( h(x) \\) modifies the initial conditions, which would alter the trajectory of the system. Since the initial position is modified by a quadratic function of time, the subsequent dynamics determined by the integro-differential equation will diverge from those of the unaltered initial condition.
